results.title: Art and motion
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Paul Burnford Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the relationships between movement in nature, in space-time concepts, and in abstract art forms. Shows the relationship between space and motion in the mobiles of Calder and Usher, in the paintings of Balla, Kadinsky and Van Gogh, and in the abstract film “Colour Fragments” by Elwood Decker.

results.title: Art and life in Italy
results.brief_description: Italy: the countryside, architecture and sculpture. Rome: the Colosseum, Pantheon, and St Peter’s Cathedral, church interiors, mosaics; a Giotto fresco. Florence: Cathedral dome and bronze doors, Medici palaces, Raphael’s painting. Botticelli’s “Adoration of the Magi”: Della Robbia’s “Singing Angels” and Michelangelo’s “Figure of Moses”. Venice : the churches. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and life in Belgium (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Henri Kerels, PDK Pictures and Charles Dekeukeleire
results.brief_description: The countryside of Flanders, Brabant and Wallonia in Belgium has for centuries attracted artists who have interpreted the changing seasons and depicted various types of inhabitants of the regions. This film shows how these sources of inspiration have remained unchanged. Comparisons of the work of artists of different periods with the landscape and types of inhabitants to be seen in Flanders and the surrounding districts today. Artists whose work is illustrated include P. Breughel, Rubens and Van Eyck.

results.title: Art
results.brief_description: Presents a short and frantic history of painting and graphics, combined with Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony. Uses an animated still-picture technique, sometimes called “kinestasis”.

results.title: Arsenic and old lace
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Howard Lindsay, Russel Crouse and Frank Capra
results.brief_description: In this black comedy, Cary Grant plays Mortimer Brewster, a drama critic about to marry Elaine Page (Priscilla Lane) who discovers that insanity runs in his family. His maiden aunts poison lonely old men, and his uncle buries the victims in the cellar. Mortimer attempts to conceal these crimes as police search for the murderer. Grant donated his fee to war relief.

results.title: Arsenal
results.brief_description:
Revolution in the Ukraine in 1917-19, culminating in the suppression of the workers’ revolt in a munition factory at Kiev, is treated symbolically, employing the dynamics of montage in an epic celebration of victory in defeat. A blend of folklore, comedy, drama and caricature. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Alexander Dovzhenko ; writers, Isaac Shpinel, Vladimir Muller ; photography, Daniel Demutski.
Cast: Semyon Svashenko, Mikola Nademsky, Ambrose Buchma, Pyotr Masokha.

results.title: Arrows against the wind
results.creator_credit: A Land Beyond Production, SBS-TV and Tracey Groome
results.brief_description: Describes the culture and traditional way of life of the indigenous peoples of West Papua (Irian Jaya), and the social, political and environmental upheaval they have endured since the beginning of Indonesian rule in 1963. Outlines their continuing struggle for social justice and self-determination.

results.title: Arrow up yours
results.creator_credit: Deborah Szapiro, Andrew Horne, Karl Kruszelnicki and Freerange Aninmation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
This entertaining animation presented by Karl Kruszelnicki explains the bow and arrow and its history and in so doing provides an explanation for the well known two finger salute. There is mention of the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, and how the well trained British used the Welsh long bow to attack the French. All this adds up to the reason behind the two finger salute.

results.title: Arrow to the sun
results.brief_description: A film which uses animation to tell the tale of the Acoma Pueblo Indians about a boy’s search for his father, entailing his voyage on an arrow to the Sun, trials he undergoes in the sky village until he is recognised by his father, the lord of the sun, and his return to earth to spread the sun’s warm delights. Based on the Caldecott Medal winning book by Gerald McDermott.
